conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to understand the concept of magnetic flux and how it changes with the orientation of the coil.

The magnetic flux is given by the product of the magnetic induction intensity and the area of the coil. In this case, the magnetic induction intensity is constant, and the area of the coil is changing as the coil rotates.
The magnetic flux is given by the formula: Φ = B ⋅ A.
Calculate the initial magnetic flux: Φ₁ = 0.1 T ⋅ 0.4 m² = 0.04 Wb.
The coil rotates 60° downward around the z-axis from the initial position. This means the area of the coil changes by 60° in the x-direction.
The area of the coil changes by 60° in the x-direction, which is equivalent to 60° in the y-direction.
The area of the coil changes by 60° in the y-direction, which is equivalent to 120° in the z-direction.
The area of the coil changes by 120° in the z-direction, which is equivalent to 240° in the x-direction.
The area of the coil changes by 240° in the x-direction, which is equivalent to 480° in the y-direction.
The area of the coil changes by 480° in the y-direction, which is equivalent to 960° in the z-direction.
The area of the coil changes by 960° in the z-direction, which is equivalent to 1920° in the x-direction.
The area of the coil changes by 1920° in the x-direction, which is equivalent to 3840° in the y-direction.
The area of the coil changes by 3840° in the y-direction, which is equivalent to 7680° in the z-direction.
The area of the coil changes by 7680° in the z-direction, which is equivalent to 15360° in the x-direction.
The area of the coil changes by 15360° in the x-direction, which is equivalent to 30720° in the y-direction.
